What is Acid Reflux?

Acid reflux occurs when stomach acid backs up into the oesophagus because the lower oesophagal sphincter does not shut correctly. It leads to heartburn – a burning sensation in the chest, and regurgitation – sour content in the throat or mouth. These signs, if experienced, frequently result in GERD, a more severe condition that affects the oesophagus.

Various causes of acid reflux are obesity, pregnancy, smoking, certain medications, and some types of foods like citrus fruits, chocolates, and fatty foods. Simple instructions like weight loss, avoiding specific foods that provoke this discomfort, and getting off the back after having a meal can ease the problem. If these changes don’t work, medications may be required.

Symptoms of Acid Reflux

The common symptoms of acid reflux include:

  • Heartburn: Heartburn mainly occurs after a meal or at night.
  • Regurgitation: A burning or metallic taste due to an accumulation of the material in the throat or mouth.
  • Chest Pain: Pain in the chest region and is usually aggravated by meals, movement, or lying down.
  • Difficulty Swallowing: Symptoms that persistently give a feeling as if there is a lump in the throat or the chest.
  • Chronic Cough: A dry cough that becomes worse at night or after eating or drinking.
  • Sore Throat or Hoarseness: Irritation in the throat, most of which I experience in the morning.
  • Bad Breath: Because acid gets to the mouth and throat.
  • Nausea: At times, it leads to vomiting after meals.

Causes of Acid Reflux

Acid reflux happens when stomach acid flows back into the oesophagus, causing discomfort and symptoms like heartburn. Understanding what causes acid reflux can help manage and prevent it. Here are some common causes:

  • Hiatal Hernia: This is a condition in which one of the parts of the stomach rises through the diaphragm into the chest cavity, making the valve (LES) that is supposed to keep stomach acids away from the food tube.
  • Obesity: Other risk factors, such as obesity, cause pressure against the abdominal area, forcing stomach content back up the food pipe and thus causing acid reflux.
  • Pregnancy: Acid reflux is very common during pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester, because hormonal changes cause the stomach to rise. This is usually relieved after childbirth.
  • Smoking: Smoking causes the LES to become weak, the stomach produces more acid, and throat muscles can be adversely affected, all of which lead to acid reflux.
  • Diet: Some foods and beverages can cause or make acid reflux worse. These include fatty or fried foods, chocolate, foods with high amounts of citric acid like oranges and tomatoes, spicy foods, garlic, onions, alcohol, soft drinks, coffee, and tea.
  • Eating Habits: Reflux symptoms may worsen if one eats large meals, lies down soon after eating, snacks just before going to bed, or bends over after a meal.
  • Medications: These drugs include aspirin, ibuprofen, muscle relaxants, and some medicines used for blood pressure.
  • Slow Digestion: Some medicines and diseases that cause Delayed gastric emptying, such as diabetes, put pressure on the stomach, hence increasing the chances of heartburn.
  • Stress: Stress does not cause acid reflux as a primary ailment but may cause situations such as overeating or eating foods that will worsen the condition.
  • Connective Tissue Disorders: Some diseases like scleroderma affect the muscles of the oesophagus through which endoscopy is accomplished and shall compromise its functionality, resulting in reflux symptoms.

    • Arsenicum Album: For burning stomach and oesophagus pain, especially worse at night.
    • Iris Versicolor: Reduces sour and bitter belching with heartburn and occasional nausea.
    • Robinia: Targets nighttime heartburn and sour vomiting.

  • Lifestyle Tips: Certain behaviors, if embraced, can enhance the outcomes of homeopathic therapies. These include avoiding foods that trigger flare-ups, achieving and maintaining a healthy weight, and managing stress.

  • Carbo Vegetabilis (Carbo Veg): Pronounced effects are observed regarding flatulence and problems associated with fullness in the stomach. It also helps with flatulence and a bad taste in the mouth.
  • Arsenicum Album: Effective for treating pain in the stomach and esophagus, particularly at night. It’s used to minimize the discomfort and anxiety that comes with acid reflux.

  • Antimonium Crudum: It has been effective in relieving discomfort caused by indigestion caused by overeating or spicy and other acidic meals in patients with GERD.

Diet & Lifestyle Changes for Acid Reflux Patients

Managing acid reflux often requires making specific dietary and lifestyle changes. Here are some key tips to help reduce symptoms:

Dietary Changes for Acid Reflux Patients

  • Identify Trigger Foods: Record foods that make your symptoms worse. Some of the strict diet plans prohibiting these foods embrace fatty foods, spicy foods, citrus fruits, tomatoes, chocolates, garlic, onions, peppermint, coke, coffee, and alcohol.
  • Eat Smaller, More Frequent Meals: Rather than having a few more massive meals, eating smaller meals at a consistent time of the day will help ease the pressure that is usually placed on the stomach and the LES.
  • Avoid Eating Before Bedtime: Do not go to bed hungry or eat a large meal before bedtime so the stomach has time to digest, causing less nighttime reflux.
  • Stay Hydrated: Drink tap water throughout the day, but don’t drink too much water with your meals because it makes your stomach puff.
  • Incorporate High-Fiber Foods: For good digestion, eat bread made from whole grains, root crops, and green leafy vegetables.
  • Limit High-Fat Foods: Reduce foods with fats as they can make the LES relax and worsen reflux.

Lifestyle Changes for Acid Reflux Patients

  • Maintain a Healthy Weight: Weight loss can help alleviate pressure on the stomach and ease any incidences of reflux.
  • Elevate the Head of Your Bed: Prop up the head end of your bed by 6-8 inches at night so that acid does not flow back up into your oesophagus.
  • Avoid Tight Clothing: Avoid tight clothing, as this puts pressure on your abdomen, which can lead to reflux, among other things.
  • Quit Smoking: ESD is further aggravated by smoking, but it disappears or improves vastly when people stop smoking.
  • Manage Stress: Stress can make acid reflux worse. Yoga, meditation, or deep breathing exercises can help reduce tension or stress.
  • Limit Alcohol: Drinking alcohol may cause the oesophagus to become more sensitive and may also cause the LES to relax, so avoiding alcohol may improve condition.
  • Practice Mindful Eating: Chew your food well and avoid eating meals while you’re under pressure or stress. This will reduce your chances of developing reflux.
